title: Shay Robert Richards sentenced to jail for crash that killed Invercargill teen Nakita Strange
text:
Shay Robert Richards sentenced to jail for crash that killed Invercargill teen Nakita Strange HAMISH MCNEILLY Last updated 11:15, February 3 2017 HAMISH McNEILLY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Shay Robert Richards, 20, in the High Court at Dunedin. 
A driver involved in a crash that killed an 18-year-old girl desperately tried to save her life, a court has heard. 
An emotional Anthony Odering read from his victim impact statement in the High Court at Dunedin as Shay Robert Richards, 20, was sentenced on Friday morning. 
Odering was the driver of a ute hit by a vehicle driven by Richards in Dunedin early on July 29, 2015. Eighteen-year-old Nakita Strange died in the crash. FACEBOOK/SUPPLIED 
Nakita Strange died in a crash in Dunedin on July 29, 2015. 
Odering and a nearby resident tried to revive Strange, who was one of four passengers in the back seat of the car Richards was driving. 
"I remembered thinking how peaceful and beautiful she looked. That mental image haunts me," Odering said. 
READ MORE: * Father yet to hear from driver ​ JAMES GUNN 
Emergency services attend the scene of a fatal crash at the intersection of Hope and Stafford streets, Dunedin. 
Justice Dunedin Gendall sentenced Richards to three years and three months' jail on five charges: reckless driving causing death, three of reckless driving causing injury, and one of theft. 
The 20-year-old pleaded guilty at his last court appearance in November, after originally pleading not guilty to the manslaughter of the Invercargill teen. 
Odering was not at fault in the crash, but had to live with what happened, Justice Gendall said HAMISH McNEILLY/FAIRFAX NZ 
The wreckage of a car involved in a fatal crash in Dunedin. 
Before reading his victim impact statement, Odering apologised to Strange's family about its graphic details. Those details still haunted him, he said. Ad Feedback 
He recalled the crash seemed to happen in slow motion, with his vehicle forced up on two wheels following the impact. 
Odering knew it was bad, and went to check on the occupants of the other car, which had ended up against a wall. HAMISH McNEILLY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Police at the scene of a fatal crash at the intersection of Hope and Stafford streets in Dunedin. 
Odering started CPR, but the first compression resulted in blood spilling from her ears. 
As a father, Odering knew that "if my daughter died in my arms I would be saying goodbye to her". 
"I said goodbye to her on behalf of her family, and kissed her on the cheek." HAMISH McNEILLY/FAIRFAX NZ 
The crash involved a Ford Laser and a Courier ute. 
Odering said he went to Invercargill to pay respects to her family, and saw a family grieving for a beloved family member. 
"The feeling Nakita's blood is on my hands is a hard one to shake." 
Richards' lawyer, Anne Stevens, said her client felt "100 per cent s..." since the crash. HAMISH McNEILLY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Flowers and messages at the site where a teen died in a car crash in Dunedin. 
He accepted responsibility for the crash and Strange's death. The teen was the only passenger in the car that he knew. 

CRASH TOOK 'BEST FRIEND' 
A victim impact statement was also read on behalf of Strange's 16-year-old brother, Quade Strange, who said he struggled with her death. 
He used to be an outgoing person, but had become withdrawn since the loss of his "best friend". 
"I find myself crying uncontrollably . . . I feel alone," his statement said. 
Quade had visited the crash site to try come to terms with his sister's death, which he blamed himself for. 
"I wish I asked her to stay." 
William Strange, the victim's brother, told Richards: "You have killed my only sister. 
"Now all we have our memories and pain. You have no idea what we are going through." 
Mark Strange said his daughter had just turned 18 and was just starting her life. 
He had received a letter from Richards, who he referred to an an "idiot". 
He urged him to get help for his drug and alcohol issues. 
Ivy Strange, 74, said her granddaughter lived with her during the last six months of her life. 
​"I hope you get what you deserve," she told Richards. 
DRIVING 'LIKE AN IDIOT' 
The four victims of Richards' crash – Strange, Liam Boniface, 19, Devin Sparrow, 20, and Xavier Sardiello, 18 – were driving from Invercargill to Christchurch. 
They realised they did not have enough money for petrol as they neared Dunedin, and Strange contacted Richards to see if he could help. 
Richards drove their Ford Laser to a BP petrol station, where they filled up with $75.54 of petrol and left without paying. 
The car skidded off, with Richards driving, his friend Kama Hurring in the front passenger seat, and Hurring, Sparrow, Boniface and Strange sitting in the back. 
No-one in the back wore seatbelts. 
The court heard Richards was a learner driver, who had never been involved in a crash before. 
Justice Gendall said the sentence had to send a message to young drivers, particularly young men. 
He sentenced Richards to three years and three months' jail, and disqualified him from driving for four years. - Stuff
